page.title: 19THE LIFE OF A MINER
page.content: It is quite difficult changing your eating habits and organising your home life when you are on a different shift every week. When Jonathan's dad is on nights he sleeps all through the morning until about 1 o'clock, so everybody has to be very quiet in the house during this time. Some men still take their 'snap' or food underground with them in a 'snap tin', an air tight tin that keeps out the coal dust. Others get a meal at the pit canteen when they come up. The cage or lift that takes the men down the shaft travels at 4 metres per second and the pressure affects your ears as you go down. The temperature gets higher as you go deeper under the ground. The coal seam they are working at the moment at Creswell is less than a metre high, so there isn't much room to work in. It's hard being a miner!
